awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Maxime O. Bergeron is "The Topology, Geometry, and Arithmetic of Representation Varieties." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Chicago, and the sponsoring scientist is Benson Farb.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to gain a deeper understanding of the interplay between topology and algebraic geometry in moduli spaces.

This research began with an investigation of spaces of representations from finitely generated groups into linear algebraic groups. These so-called representation varieties are naturally endowed with an algebraic group action corresponding to the symmetries arizing between representations. As such, key aspects of the project required a topological understanding of the corresponding geometric invariant theory quotients. This turns out to be a central problem in the study of other moduli spaces, such as spaces of rational maps, where the topology of these quotients remained a mystery. 

Several new results were produced. In particular, in joint work with L. Silberman, a complete description of the topology of the moduli space of Baumslag-Solitar representations in reductive groups was given. This class of groups sits at an interesting juncture from the point of view of the topology of its representations as the simplest interesting infinite groups which are not lattices in Lie groups. In another direction, in joint work with K. Filom and S. Nariman, a description of the topology of the space of Mobius conjugacy classes of degree d rational maps on the Riemann sphere was produced. These spaces are interesting due to their ubiquity in dynamics and their status as fundamental examples to explore links between topology, algebraic geometry and number theory. The corresponding publications are all available for free on arxiv.org.

In addition to these activities, the PI ran multiple workshops for middle schoolers through the Math Circles of Chicago and served as a judge for QED: Chicago's Youth Math Symposium.
